results.title: The Nature of prejudice: ' I wear my people's clothes'
results.creator_credit: Playing With Time, Canadian Council of Christians and Jews, Linda Schuyler and Kit Hood
results.brief_description: Attempts to break down people’s prejudices to people of other cultures by putting forward the view that prejudice is the result of fear based on lack of understanding. Interviews several people of ethnic origins living in Canada who still follow the customs and beliefs of their own cultures, including the wearing of particular clothing and hairstyles. Narrated by Professor Jamshed Mavalwala. Suitable for upper primary, lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: The Nature of paradise (A)
results.creator_credit: Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television, Steve Thomas, Daryl Dellora, Sally Ingleton, John Moore and Lucinda Gamble
results.brief_description: Three women - Trish Molloy (artist), Monique La Fontaine (artist), Sharon Wiggan (law student) - tell their stories, each from a personal perspective, of their relationship and connection to the Western Australian north-west coastal town of Broome. Trish and Monique are travellers who have separately found their way to Broome and stayed and Sharon is an Aboriginal Australian who was brought up in Broome, left to study in Perth and who has now returned home to Broome. The documentary explores each woman’s emotional and spiritual attachment to the town, to their surrounding environment and their kinship with the people of Broome and with each other. Evocative and beautifully photographed by Veronica Iacono, and sensitively scripted and directed by Lucinda Gamble, “The Nature of paradise” is stunningly rich in images and colour, of reds and blues, of the earth, sky and the ocean and is accompanied by an ambient musical soundtrack, “Free diving” written and performed by Lorrei Coffin. Interspersed throughout the documentary are images of both Trish and Monique’s paintings which reflect their transitional journey to this place called “paradise”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television, Steve Thomas, Daryl Dellora, Sally Ingleton, John Moore and Lucinda Gamble

results.title: The Nature of Light
results.creator_credit: Coronet Instructional Films and David A. Smart
results.brief_description: Two teenage boys (Bud and Sandy) on a camping trip, demonstrate the uses of light through various practical experiments. Demonstrations include: the law of reflection, differences between convex and concave lenses, how the eye works etc.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Coronet Instructional Films and David A. Smart

results.title: The Nature of life: the living cell
results.brief_description: Photomicrography investigates single-celled and multi-celled organisms - how they produce or absorb food, convert food to energy, respond to their environments, and reproduce. Simple experiments seen through a standard microscope demonstrate the functions of cell structures; an electron microscope reveals smaller cell structures.

results.title: The Nature of life: respiration in animals
results.brief_description: Explores the similarities of air-breathing and water-breathing animals, developing this concept through the animal kingdom to man himself. Demonstrations show the vital relationships between the animal’s size and the complexity of its respiratory system - between respiration, blood circulation and feeding.

results.title: The Nature of heat
results.brief_description: Explains heat as the energy of molecular motion. Experiments are used to demonstrate that heat is transferred by conduction, convection and radiation. Shows the effectiveness of various types of material in the transfer of heat.
results.description: Explains heat as the energy of molecular motion. Experiments are used to demonstrate that heat is transferred by conduction, convection and radiation. Shows the effectiveness of various types of material in the transfer of heat.

results.title: The Nature and development of affection
results.brief_description: An experiment with chimpanzees. One animal is placed in a compartment with a wired cage source of milk, a “wire mother”, another is placed with a similar wire source of milk but this is covered with a furry material and is known as the “cloth mother”. Experiments contrast the social behaviour and the amount of affection which grows with each animal and “mother”. Towards the end a human baby is shown to be attracted to a cloth mother. The University of Wisonsin Department of Psychology, Primate Laboratory with Dr. Harry F. Harlow.

results.title: The Natural
results.creator_credit: Tri-Star Pictures, Delphi II, Mark Johnson and Barry Levinson
results.brief_description: Based on the novel by Bernard Malamud, “The Natural” is one of those heroic, feel good, fairy tale films that captures the human spirit. It is a tale of boyhood dreams, of a certain defiance to turn the dream into reality and become a legend and a superhero in that passionate game of American games, baseball, and of a chance encounter with a mysterious woman that will eventually and catastrophically shatter those very dreams. Robert Redford plays the quiet and unassuming middle-aged Roy Hobbs who at the age of 14 hand-carved his own baseball bat from a tree struck down by lightning on the farm where he lived. It was Roy’s dream to play baseball in the major league and it would be his “wonder boy” bat many years later that would take him to stardom and the major league team, the New York Knights. But like all fairy tales, where good and evil battle it out, Hobbs has his own demons to deal with in the form of knockers, corruption and those who would wish to see him, and the New York Knights, fail. The story climaxes to a tense and spectacular final sequence as our hero takes the bat in a nail-biting challenge to win the pennant for his Knights. This is not a film to be taken too seriously and there are many holes in the plot, but it features a wonderful cast including Glenn Close, Kim Basinger, Robert Duvall, Barbara Hershey, Richard Farnsworth and an uncredited appearance by Darren McGavin.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tri-Star Pictures, Delphi II, Mark Johnson and Barry Levinson
